awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Aukosh S. Jagannath is "Variational and Structural Problems in Spin Glasses." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Toronto, and the sponsoring scientist is Dmitry Panchenko. 

This award was supported with funding from the Office of International Science & Engineering.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to continue the development of a mathematically rigorous mean field theory for spin glasses. A rigorous understanding of the mean field theory of spin glasses has been a central problem in mathematical physics and probability since the late 1970s which has been studied by many leading figures in these fields. In the past decade there has been a tremendous amount of progress on this theory. During the course of this proposal, the PI established several fundamental results conjectured in the physics literature, such as the Thouless--Anderson--Palmer equations. The PI has also developed novel approaches to understanding the dynamics and ground state energy of such systems. 

While this proposal centered around a class of problems which are traditionally classified as analysis or probability theory, the research developed has had a much broader impact: it has immediate applications to several other fields such as theoretical computer science, high-dimensional statistics, and data science. In particular, the PI and collaborators have developed a new approach to the dynamics of spin glasses that has lead to important insights in the analysis of the average case performance of gradient descent in an important problem in the mathematics of data science. Results of this type are central problems  in machine learning, data science, and  high-dimensional statistics.

The secondary goal is to develop the PIs career skills during a post-doctoral period. During the proposal period the PI had several opportunities to do so, such mentoring Ph D students, teaching courses, in particular an advanced graduate level course on this research.

Modified by: Aukosh S Jagannath
